case_vignette: A 52-year-old male presents to his primary care physician at the insistence of his wife who reports that he has been complaining of vague abdominal pain over the last several months. She asks if you think her husband's skin appears yellow. Vitals signs and laboratory findings are as follows: T 98.7F, HR 73, BP 114/68, RR 14, O2 100%. Hemoglobin 9.7, Hematocrit 31.2, WBC 6, Platelets 146. Amylase and lipase are within normal limits. You order a CT scan (Figure A).
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Gastrointestinal System. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. I haven't traveled recently or been exposed to new environments.

I haven't noticed any changes in my stress levels or how I've been sleeping.
Have you had any recent changes in your medication or supplements?
I haven't made any changes to my medications or supplements recently.
Have you had any recent changes in your family history or medical history?
No recent changes in my family or medical history.
Final Diagnosis: Malabsorption.
